election_record.label: New York 1810 Governor

overview.note: "It is no longer to be doubted, from intelligence received from the western part of the state, but that the people of this state are about to be again compelled to submit to the misrule of democracy. The 'lovely' Tompkins is undoubtedly re-elected, and there is great reason to fear that there is a democratic majority in the Assembly. But in this general scene of political distress, it is proudly consoling to be able to state, that the citizens of Columbia County have once more done their duty - that the Federalism of this county acquires strength with every new exercise of the right of suffrage, as will appear from the following canvas of the votes for the present year--" Northern Whig (Hudson, NY). May 4, 1810.

"By illegal and improper returns, 1717 votes were rejected, 1081 of which were for Tompkins, and 636 for Platt. There were 86 scattering votes, 1 of which were designed for Tompkins, 54 for Platt, and 19 for other persons." Political Barometer (Poughkeepsie, NY). June 27, 1810.
Vote totals for towns sometimes vary very slightly by source (by 1 or 2 votes here or there).

"We cannot forbear noticing the votes rejected on account of the illegal returns, viz. [for Daniel D. Tompkins, and Jonas Platt, respectively, by votes by town as follows:]...Flushing 71 [and] 65 / Rye 51 [and] 24 / Woodstock 33 [and] 55 / Rockland 28 [and] 5 / Champlain 37 [and] 52 / Butternuts 144 [and] 99 / Redfield 54 [and] 3 / Lysander 55 [and] 31 / Niagara county 571 [and] 312 / De Ruyter 37 [and 0]/ Total 1081 [and] 636 [votes for Daniel D. Tompkins and Jonas Platt, rejected.] Majority of 445 for Tompkins lost. Had all the good votes been legally returned, it appears that governor Tompkins' majority would have been 7055." Bunker-Hill (Herkimer, NY). May 10, 1810. The Columbian (New York, NY) of June 21 and The Albany Register (Albany, NY) of June 19 report the same total votes (1,081 and 636), but differs for towns of Rye and Woodstock with Jonas Platt listed with 34 and 35 votes in those towns.

"'The Election. We did hope to be able to lay before our readers to-day, a complete statement of the votes given in this county at the late election; but as two or three towns are not officially returned, we must omit it till next week. According to the returns made, and what we have heard, the democratic assembly ticket is elected by a majority of about 400; and the democratic candidates for governor and senators have a majority of 8 or 10.....We hope to be able to give our friends better news next week.' From the above we may see the result of federal predictions, and the credit due to federal newspapers." The Columbian (New York, NY). May 12, 1810.

sub_unit.name: Two
sub_unit.note: The Albany Register (Albany, NY) of June 22 lists Daniel D. Tompkins with 64 votes.

sub_unit.name: Colonie
sub_unit.note: Daniel D. Tompkins received 1 vote as Doniel D. Topkins and 1 vote as Donnul D. Tomcens which were not included in the official results.

sub_unit.note: The votes from Champlin were rejected as no office was designated.

sub_unit.name: Essex
sub_unit.note: Jonas Platt received 22 votes as Jonar Platt which were not included in the official results.

The Columbian (New York, NY) lists Daniel D. Tompkins with 1888 votes.

sub_unit.note: The Columbian (New York, NY) lists Daniel D. Tompkins with 125 votes.

sub_unit.note: The Columbian (New York, NY) lists Daniel D. Tompkins with 139 votes.

sub_unit.name: Berlin
sub_unit.note: The Farmer's Register of May 8 lists Jonas Platt with 184 votes.

sub_unit.name: Saratoga
sub_unit.note: The Independent American (Ballston Spa, NY) and The Columbian (New York, NY) list Daniel D. Tompkins with 1846 votes.
The Independent American (Ballston Spa, NY) and The Columbian (New York, NY) list Jonas Platt with 1392 votes.

sub_unit.name: Ballston
sub_unit.note: The New York Journal of June 27 lists Jonas Platt with 14 votes (which is likely a misprint).

sub_unit.name: Greenfield
sub_unit.note: The Independent American (Ballston Spa, NY) and The Columbian (New York, NY) list Daniel D. Tompkins with 195 votes.
The American Monitor (Plattsburg) of July 7 lists Jonas Platt with 115 votes.

sub_unit.name: Moreau
sub_unit.note: The Independent American (Ballston Spa, NY) and The Columbian (New York, NY) list Jonas Platt with 29 votes.

sub_unit.name: Duanesburgh
sub_unit.note: The New York Journal of June 27 lists Daniel D. Tompkins with 126 votes.

sub_unit.name: Putnam
sub_unit.note: The New York Journal of June 27 lists Daniel D. Tompkins with 6 votes.

sub_unit.name: Columbia
sub_unit.note: "COLUMBIA COUNTY--THE ELECTION In this county has as usual terminated in favor of federalism. The federal candidates for assembly, James Vanderpoel, Augustus Tremain, Jacob R. Van Rensselaer and Thomas P. Grosvenor have succeeded by a majority of 593--100 less than last year. In this city their majority is lessened 48. The federal candidates for congress, Robert Le Roy Livingston and Asa Fitch, have a majority of 597. The federal majority for governor is 529 for lieut. governor 558, for senator 582. The increase of federal majority for governor is attended with circumstances which we shall hereafter notice. We shall here merely mention that villainy, bribery, corruption and intrigue, have went [sic] hand in hand with federalism through the election. Every thing that wore the shape of a human being, black or white, was worth one hundred pounds, long enough, at least, to vote for Jonas Platt, [and etc.] almost every negro in this city had the honor of voting for that gentleman. The art of making voters has been practised so much by federalists, that they now think it no crime, and almost do it openly; the under strappers to the bull-dog, and the rest of the royal family, even boast of it in the public streets--to use their own words, "we are the boys that's able to make voters." But enough of this for the present. This election has proved fatal to federalism--republicanism is again triumphant. New York has followed the example of N. [sic] Hampshire, Massachusetts and Rhode Island. Notwithstanding the intrigue carried on by the federalists, and notwithstanding Jackson settled in the capital of our state to aid federalism in its villainy, the people have come forward in defence [sic] of their rights and liberties, and have given a large majority for Daniel D. Tomkins to be their servant, instead of electing Jonas Platt to be their master. [Bee.]" The Albany Register (Albany, NY). May 11, 1810.

sub_unit.name: Hillsdale
sub_unit.note: Jonas Platt received 7 votes as James Platt.

sub_unit.name: Kinderhook
sub_unit.note: Daniel D. Tompkins received 1 vote as Daniel D. Tompskins.
Jonas Platt received 1 vote as Janas Platt and 1 vote as Jenas Platt.

sub_unit.name: Patterson
sub_unit.note: The Political Barometer lists Patterson as Franklin.
The American Monitor (Plattsburg) of July 7 lists Daniel D. Tompkins with 45 votes.

sub_unit.name: Stanford

sub_unit.name: Sullivan
sub_unit.note: The American Monitor (Plattsburg) does not include the votes from Rockland because they were rejected.

sub_unit.name: Rockland
sub_unit.note: The votes in Rockland are not included in some sources because they were rejected.

sub_unit.name: Ulster
sub_unit.note: Daniel D. Tompkins received 1 vote as Daniel Tompkins which was not included in the official results.
The American Monitor (Plattsburg) does not include the votes from Woodstock because they were rejected; it lists Daniel D. Tompkins with 1054 votes and Jonas Platt with 943 votes.
Plebeian (Kingston, NY) of May 8 lists Daniel D. Tompkins with votes in towns of Ulster County that add up to 1096 votes.

sub_unit.name: New Paltz
sub_unit.note: Plebeian (Kingston, NY) lists Daniel D. Tompkins with 170 votes.

sub_unit.name: Woodstock
sub_unit.note: The votes in Woodstock were rejected, as no office was designated, as is noted by the American Monitor (Plattsburg) of July 7.

sub_unit.name: Kings
sub_unit.note: "Majority for D. D. Tompkins 4." The Long Island Star (Brooklyn, NY). May 3, 1810.

sub_unit.name: New York
sub_unit.note: Daniel D. Tompkins and Nicholas Platt each received 1 vote that was not included in the official totals because of a misspelling.

sub_unit.name: Queens
sub_unit.note: The American Monitor (Plattsburg) does not include the votes from Flushing because they were rejected; it lists Daniel D. Tompkins with 730 votes and Jonas Platt with 715 votes.

sub_unit.name: Flushing
sub_unit.note: The votes in Flushing were rejected, no office being designated.
The American Citizen (New York, NY) of April 28 lists Daniel D. Tompkins with 79 votes in Flushing.

sub_unit.name: North Hempstead
sub_unit.note: Official results list Daniel D. Tompkins with 95 votes. This contradicts other reports and would give Tompkins 10 votes more for the total county than he is reported as having.
The Albany Register (Albany, NY) of June 22 lists Daniel D. Tompkins with 95 votes.

sub_unit.name: Southampton
sub_unit.note: Daniel D. Tompkins received 1 vote as Daniel T. Tompkins.

sub_unit.name: Westchester
sub_unit.note: Jonas Platt received 15 votes as Johan Platt and 1 vote as Jonas Patt that were not included in the official results.

The American Monitor (Plattsburg) does not include the votes from Rye because they were rejected, or the votes under misspelled names in its totals; it lists Daniel D. Tompkins with 1148 votes and Jonas Platt with 1085 votes.

The New-York Spectator (New York, NY) of May 2, 1810 only lists majorities for Governor by party, not name of candidate. Federal majorities are listed in Bedford Somers, Mamaroneck, Greenburgh, New-Rochelle, White-Plains, East-Chester, Yorktown and North-Castle, for a total Federal majority in those towns of 229. Democratic majorities are listed in Westchester, Harrison, Yonkers, Scarsdale, Mount-Pleasant, Pelham, Rye, Cortlandt, Poundridge, South-Salem and North-Salem, for a total Democratic majority in those towns of 308. This implies a Democratic majority for Westchester County of 79, however because of the 15 votes this paper lists as "consequently lost" in Bedford, the difference in the county amounts to 64 (which is also the difference between the 1199 an 1135 figures listed above for the county totals for the two leading candidates.

sub_unit.name: Bedford
sub_unit.note: The American Monitor (Plattsburg) of July 7 lists Jonas Platt with 152 votes and may be a misprint with the 2 and 5 reversed.
In Bedford 15 votes were given for Jonah Platt and consequently lost." New-York Spectator (New York, NY). May 2, 1810.

sub_unit.name: Harrison
sub_unit.note: The American Monitor (Plattsburg) of July 7 lists Daviel D. Tompkins with 33 votes.

sub_unit.name: Rye
sub_unit.note: The votes in Rye were rejected as no office was designated (as reported in the American Monitor (Plattsburg) of July 7).

sub_unit.name: Western
sub_unit.note: "Steuben and Allegany Meeting. At a meeting of Delegates from the different towns in the counties of Steuben and Allegany, held at the house of Christopher Hurlbut, in the town of Canisteo, on the 20th Feb. 1810--George Hornell, Esq. was chosen Chairman, and Col. Luke Goodspeed, Secretary. The meeting was opened by Col. Samuel S. Haight, in a concise and impressive Speech, in which he called on the meeting to direct their attention towards the embarrassed state of our revenue, commerce and foreign relations, and clearly pointed out the propriety and necessity of a change in our rulers--whereupon it was Resolved unanimously, That we do cordially concur in the nomination made by the district convention, held at Skaneateles, on the 16th January last, of our worthy fellow-citizen, JONAS PLATT, Esq. Of Oneida county, as a suitable character for the office of GOVERNOR." The Geneva Gazette (Geneva, NY). February 28, 1810.

"The majority for governor Tompkins in the county of Cayuga is 1311, and in the western district computed at 5000. -- P.S. Steuben and Allegany are federal still, it seems, the former member of assembly being elected by about 40 majority, and about the same number for Platt. St. Lawrence only is to hear from. And the assembly now stands 70 to 39, and three to hear from." The Columbian (New York, NY). May 11, 1810.

sub_unit.name: Allegany
sub_unit.note: Daniel D. Tompkins received 1 vote as Daniel D. Tompk which was not included in the official results.

sub_unit.name: Broome
sub_unit.note: Although the New York Journal lists some different town totals within Broome County, it lists the same Broome County totals as other sources.

sub_unit.note: The New York Journal of June 30 lists Jonas Platt with 10 votes.

The New York Journal of June 27 lists Daniels D. Tompkins with 97 votes.

sub_unit.name: Redfield
sub_unit.note: The votes from Redfield were not included in the official results as they were listed as incomplete

The New York Journal of June 30 lists Daniel D. Tompkins with 1175 and Jonas Platt with 853 total votes, however this does not include votes from Lysander.

sub_unit.name: Lysander
sub_unit.note: The votes from Lysander were not included in the official results as they were listed as incomplete.
The New York Journal notes that the return from Lysander was incomplete and does not include any numbers for the town.
The Columbian Gazette (Utica, NY), The Albany Register (Albany, NY), The Columbian (New York, NY) and The Pilot (Cazenovia, NY) list Daniel D. Tompkins with 33 votes.

sub_unit.name: Lima

Eleven votes for Daniel D. Tompkins were not reported in the Official State Wide Canvass. The Original Town Certificate reads: "Daniel D. Tompkings and John Broome, eleven votes not designated on the face of them but indorsed on the back of each ticket for 'Governor.'"
The New York Journal lists Daniel D. Tomkins with 66 votes.
